titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. There was this morning an eclipse of the Sun—5 1/2 digits— Began at half past nine, and finished just at Noon— The sky above the City vapours was clear, but the smoke from the chimnies formed such a continual Cloud that the eclipse could be but very indistinctly seen. The severity of the cold scarcely abated at-all. I wrote a note to Count Romanzoff, asking a Passport for Mr Lawler, and at the same time requesting an interview with the Count— He appointed me this Evening at nine O’Clock— Mr Lawler came and told me he should not be ready to go sooner than Wednesday— I walked before dinner, and wrote as much in the course of the day as I was able— At nine in the Evening I went to Count Romanzoff’s, and had with him the conversation I had requested— My object was to ascertain whether any commercial arrangements were making between this Country, which might effect the trade between Russia and the United States— Chiefly upon suggestions in a letter I have received from Mr Hazard. I mentioned to the Count the present state of our affairs with England. The failure of all the attempts to negotiate for a suspension of hostilities; and the prospect that the War must continue at least through the greatest part of the ensuing Summer, even if the Emperor’s Mediation should eventually succeed in accomplishing a Peace— Under these Circumstances I had been questioned in behalf of persons interested in the commerce between Russia and the United States, whether there had been or was likely to be any Understanding between Russia, and Great-Britain, particularly with regard to the subject of articles of Contraband— The Count said there neither had been nor was likely to be any such Understanding— That with
England, Russia had simply made Peace, and the Events of the French War, had since so entirely absorbed their attention, that they had not yet had time to talk about commerce— That with regard to articles of Contraband, [“]you know,[”] said he [“]that our religion here is different from that of the English— But there have been a great many faults committed in Europe— Such is the pressure of the most important interests, that it is impossible to have more than one Ally— There is but one power on each side— If questions about articles of Contraband arise in England we shall adhere to our own system and make our claims accordingly— But they will probably adhere to their side too— There is no list of contraband adjusted between us; nor will they perhaps consider themselves bound by that stipulated in our Treaty of Commerce with them, to which the subsequent War with them has put an end— They may recur to their most comprehensive list of contraband, and at this time we can hardly think of contesting with them on that point”— I said that in regard to the interest of Russia in her trade with America, almost all her articles of export, Hemp, Sail-Cloth, and even Iron, were Articles which the English styled contraband— But my business only was to know the fact as he had candidly stated it to me, and I should with his permission make it known to those who had consulted me concerning it, and they must arrange their commercial speculation accordingly— He said, that without naming him I might give this as the real state of things, from the best information I could collect— That there was no caution valide, that the English would recognize or respect any list of contraband other than that which they always allowed— That with respect to commerce, no change had yet been made in the Tariff of the last two years— Probably little or none would be made— The Tarriff had indeed not yet been renewed; but it would be decided upon, within another fortnight, for he knew the Emperor had again been applied to for his decision. He himself knew of it no more than what was current about the Town—for he attended none of the meetings of the Council— When he went away with the Emperor last Spring; all his Presidencies (in the Council) had been transferred to Marshal Soltykoff— He still retains them—and I, added the Count, being still in the condition of a Man for whom the Emperor may send from day to day the order to join him, though I do not know whether he will; yet in the mean time I cannot attend at the meetings of the Council; appearing under the Presidency of Marshal Soltykoff, my equal in rank; but over whom my previous situation in the Council had given me precedency— He then asked me some questions with regard to the popularity of the War between the United States and Britain, as well in England as in America— I said that in America the War was popular in some parts of the Country, and unpopular in others— I told him what I had heard concerning the probable issue of the Presidential election, and my belief that Mr Madison would be re-elected— He said that his information led to the same expectation— As to the popularity of the War in England I said I was afraid it would be too popular with all parties— The only point upon which the war now was continued was that of the impressment of our Sailors— On this point the whole English Nation, or at least all the political parties were unreasonable and the loss of two of their frigates successively, captured by American frigates had mortified their national pride, and touched their point of honour, in its tenderest part— I was afraid it had embittered them, and would make them think they must now fight not only for their honour but for revenge— He asked me what I thought of the War by Land— I answered that I expected for the present little or nothing from it— We were all too raw and unskilled in War to make much progress in Canada— He asked if the People of that Province itself were not inclined to favour our Cause, and to join the American Union?— I answered there might be some of them so disposed, but I placed no reliance upon it— He asked whether I thought there was any disposition in the present British Ministry towards a General Peace, and noticed a remark said to have been made by Lord Castlereagh in Parliament; that the successes of Russia had among other good results that of making it possible to conclude a Peace— I said that observation had been afterwards explained in a Ministerial Paper, not to mean Peace with the Emperor Napoleon— But the English Ministry appeared to think that the late Events had rendered the restoration of the throne of France to the family of Bourbon probable; in which case they suppose Peace may be made without difficulty— The Count said he had not seen this explanation; but he believed this Winter would produce events of the highest importance and the most extraordinary nature, arising from the late occurrences of the War— But it was impossible to foresee precisely what they would be— It was a Chaos, as he had told the Emperor, and no one could yet imagine what system of order would finally arise from it.— But what did I think of the strength of the British Ministry at present?—and what the likelihood of any change in it?— I thought the Ministry incomparably stronger than they were when ultimately formed last Summer— But would not the English Nation be urgent for Peace?— The English Nation
would never ask for Peace, so long as their Ministers could fire the Park and Tower Guns, and talk to them of victories over the French; whether they were their own or those of their allies— As to a change of Ministers I saw no probability of that— The old opposition had not the most distant prospect of coming in—the Wellesley family little more— Mr Canning probably might come in, but the only change of system that could produce would be an increase of rancour in the War with America— But why did I think the prospects of the Wellesley’s so bad?— There was some delicacy in mentioning part of my reasons for this opinion, but I hoped he would consider me as speaking altogether in Confidence to him of it— The private character of the Marquis of Wellesley was disreputable in England— His conduct on the Catholic question was unpopular— The bigoted Church-party thought he favoured the Catholics too much, and the Catholic party had no confidence in his sincerity.— His political system was in no better favour with the public— He was for doubling and redoubling all the efforts and sacrifices of the English in Spain— It was evident enough that this system was adapted to his brother’s glory, and his own family aggrandizement, but the People were not of the same opinion, and had not the same motives. They thought the English were doing quite enough in Spain; particularly in the expenditure of money; which the Nation felt more severely than their losses of men— The Count observed that since Count Lieven’s arrival in England he had yet received from him only one or two despatches; and they mentioned that he should soon afterwards speak of American affairs— He spoke of the blockade by the English of Chesapeake Bay, and Delaware river, which I told him was another illegal blockade; for which I could perceive no other motive than a small malice against the Cities of Philadelphia and Baltimore— If they expected any good effects to themselves from this measure I trusted they would be disappointed— There was another thing in which I had seen a symptom of petty malice against America— They had made up a story that our Minister in France had followed the Emperor Napoleon to Moscow, to make a Treaty with him against Spain; which was certainly a falsehood— The Count said it was true that Mr Barlow, with the Danish Minister and a third diplomatic character from a state supposed to be in the interest of France, had been sent for to Willna; by an invitation from the Duke of Bassano— But that only one of them had arrived there; and that after Napoleon had left it— There had been even some dispositions made as if a stay of sometime in Lithuania had been contemplated— But the issue of the War had given a different turn to things— I said that Mr Barlow for aught I knew might have been sent for to Willna—but assuredly he never could go there for the object alledged by the English Newspapers, and by Mr Canning in Parliament. As to the Emperor Napoleon, his campaign had terminated in disappointment; and placed him in a situation which I considered as extremely precarious— But he had nobody to thank for it but himself— He was one more example of a head turned by Prosperous Fortune, and he must abide by the consequences of his insanity— True it is said the Count, that he must thank himself for his present condition— How many—many times have I urged upon the Duke de Vicence, sitting on this very Canapé, the preservation of Peace!— I did not repeat the same to Count Lauriston; because although I had every reason to be satisfied with his conduct personally to me, I was not upon the same terms of intimacy with him as I had been with his predecessor. The Duke de Vicence himself, I believe was of the same opinion— His inclinations were pacific; but they were unavailing— He was in a sort of disgrace; but he seems now to have come into favour again, and was the only person who accompanied Napoleon in his late return to Paris— I said I had heard that Count Lauriston was dead— There was such a report he answered— That he had been found frozen to death in his Carriage; and it was not improbable; as no mention was made of him among the Generals and Ministers who followed Napoleon upon his return to Paris.— It was probable too that Lauriston’s death might be hastened by chagrin at the idea of having contributed by his Counsels to the ruin of the army— For it is said to have been by his advice, against the opinion of Caulaincourt and of all the other Generals, qu’il fit la sottise de Moscou— It was Napoleon’s own opinion—and Lauriston flattered him by concurring with it— Not from base motives, but because it was his real opinion—that by pushing on to Moscow, we should be induced to negotiate—and if terms of Peace not too severe should be offered us, we should accept them— It was now scarcely credible how complete the destruction of that immense army had been— And they could no longer disguise it— He had seen a letter from the Duke of Bassano, written at Berlin, to some of the French agents in which were these identical words— “Il faut avouer que les Circonstances ne nous sont pas favorables.”
I observed that this was by no means disclosing a secret— The Count replied that it was not— But that it shewed that their acknowledgment of the fact became every day more complete— The details surpassed every thing that imagination could have anticipated. It was remarkable that at Dresden, the very spot which Napoleon had chosen for his point of departure, where in May last he had made such a pompous and ridiculous display of power—where he had assembled Emperors and kings, and distributed their seats at the Elector’s table, and published them in all his Gazettes as if he had been there a monarch surrounded by his vassals—that exactly there on his return, he entered the City, in a single sledge; without servants; without guards— His very Mammeluke had been frozen to death; and he was obliged to borrow four thousand Louis of the Elector, to continue his journey, and six shirts from his Minister.— At Weimar, he had passed through without stopping, and left an apology behind to the Duke for not having visited him—that he was absolutely not in a presentable condition— (N.B. the Duchess of Weimar is a Russian Grand-Duchess— Sister of the Emperor Alexander—) at Weimar; he could not go any further in his sledge—which was broken— But borrowed the town-carriage of Monsieur de Saint-Aignan, his Minister, the brother-in-Law of the Duke de Vicence, and who was some time here with him; and with this Carriage, and two soldiers lent him by the Elector of Saxony he reached Paris— It was truly singular that Saxony should have been the particular scene of these humiliations—that very Saxony where he had made such a display of the Colonies of farmers and Artists, and God knows what, that he had brought with his army to settle in Poland.— Since his arrival in Paris, it was said he was sick—that he was certainly gone to Marli; on the pretext of hunting; and there he might be sick, and confine himself to the Palace, without so much notice as it would occasion at Paris— There was also a Report current about the City, and related with so many circumstances of detail as rendered it highly probable, that there had been a great popular Insurrection at Munich in Bavaria— But I have had, said the Count, no official advice of it myself— For the Emperor has naturally directed the Courier’s who had despatches to me, to proceed to his own Head-Quarters, and has opened the packets addressed to me— Thus far my Conversation with the Count; of which as of all the others I have with him I give the most particular relation, omitting only the common chat about weather, my family, and objects of no general or particular interest, which are occasionally mingled with them— The Circumstances which most struck me this time were those which the Count mentioned respecting himself—and which seemed to indicate an apprehension of declining favour— It was near eleven at Night when I came home— Still bitter cold— Thermometer Morn -23:8 Noon -20:7, Eve -22:7.

2. I wrote Count Löwenhielm a Note, requesting a Courier’s Passport for him, to travel through Sweden— He soon after sent me one, but he had forgotten to sign it.— I was employed the remainder of the day in writing to America— An operation which in the excessive cold still prevailing I find very difficult— I walk now only before dinner— This Evening soon after dinner I found myself so much overpowered by drowsiness;—that I was obliged to betake myself between 8 and 9 to bed— This is one of the effects of the weather; and to my great mortification it disqualifies me totally from reading, and even from giving instruction to Charles. -23:2, -21:5, -20:5.

3. Mr Lawler was here twice this day— In the Morning, before I had received his Passport, from Count Romanzoff, and in the Evening when I had it and gave it to him, with that of Count Löwenhielm, which Mr Smith had taken to him and got signed, and with my dispatches and letters for America; all which I had enclosed to Mr Beasley in London. The difficulty of writing and the cold continues; but this Evening I was able to read a little, not much; in Voltaire— I found the cold in walking severer than the preceding days— The thermometer is not lower— But the wind being westerly, from the gulph adds dampness to the atmosphere, which makes the same degree of cold, more piercing and painful to the feelings. -21:8. -19. -20.

4. Morning visit from Mr Harris; who felicitated me upon the approaching marriage of W. S. Smith and Catherine Johnson— The weather moderated this day several degrees, and there was a considerable fall of Snow— It shortened my walk; but although the temperature of my chamber made it easier to write than it has been these many days, I wrote less— Voltaire says so much about the Chaldean, and Chinese Astronomical observations, that I wanted to enquire something about them, from better testimony than Voltaire— I looked into the Dictionaire Historique— Goguet— Count John Potocki’s Chronologies— Lenglet Dufresnoy’s Tablettes— Smith’s Essays. History of Astronomy—and Schubert’s Popular Astronomy— I found some information, but it absorbed almost the whole day— Part of the Evening however I played with Charles, and the grammatical Counters; and closed it with the family at Cards—we were all once more together at dinner, and in the Evening. -19. -13:9. -15:3.

5. The Sun now rises at 8 in the morning, and sets at 4 in the afternoon— I sometimes rise with the morning dawn; but almost always yet by candle-light— The abatement of the cold yesterday was only momentary, and this day it resumed all its rigour, with a clear sky, and almost a calm. I wrote a little more than yesterday, and read several chapters in Desodoard’s History of Louis 15. and after dinner in Voltaire’s Essai sur les Moeurs—a composition of infidelity and obscenity which I find more and more disgusting.— This work he often repeats was composed for the illustre Marquise du Chatelêt; a woman who was a sort of mixture of Pope’s Phryne and Artemisia; with whom Voltaire, lived some time in a sort of community of goods with several others— Insomuch that he had the impudence to tell her once, when she was with child, that her infant must be called Oeuvres mélées de Madame du Chatelet.— This Book is in the form of an Epistle or continual address to her; and it is not slight indication of the character both of the persons and of the age and Nation, that such a Book should publickly and avowedly have been given to the world as composed for the instruction of a married woman of rank, fashion, and extraordinary learning.— I also looked a little further into the Books that I have upon Chronology— But they are so few, and refer to so many others not within my reach, that I cannot obtain full satisfaction upon the points concerning which I was enquiring— I have however found enough to convince me that all the pretended antiquities of Egypt, Chaldea, and China, beyond, and even far short of the Scripture Chronology are fabulous— The conjunction of the five Planets with the Sun and Moon said to have been observed in China about 2500 years before the Christian Æra is the remotest fact of which there is any good evidence, and even that is strongly contested. -18:5. -20:3. -25:3

6. Mr Ducorneau paid me a Morning visit— He is going to Sweden, England and America; and desirous of obtaining a Courier’s Passport. He is a Citizen of the United States, but a Frenchman born— Mr Plummer some time ago told me, that he had heard Passports were refused in England to all persons of this description— Mr Ducorneau says he had heard so too— But that he knows Mr Charlesteguy and Mr Lasallette, who went from here the last Autumn, obtained Passports in England without any difficulty, and embarked from Liverpool for America— I therefore told Mr Ducorneau, that I would ask Courier’s Passports for him, if he could make his arrangements to go at a sufficient interval of time—eight or ten days from that of Mr Dimond’s departure— Mr Lys the principal Clerk of the House of Colombi called upon me, and mentioned that they had received from Mr Daschkoff a letter concerning me; of which he read me an extract— Mr Daschkoff says that Mr Gallatin had spoken to him, on a suggestion from me, to enquire, whether it would suit his convenience to receive his Salary at Washington upon my drafts on the Treasury, while I should receive the equivalent upon his drafts here— And he requests the Colombi’s (His bankers here) to see if they could make the arrangement with me here— But the only way in which Mr Lys thought it could be done, would be by taking the Exchange upon Amsterdam for the standard of the money which they should furnish me here— And this was precisely the thing which I wished to avoid by the arrangement.— I told him that I had no motive for changing the mode in which I now receive my Salary, but to be relieved from the loss of Exchange upon Amsterdam— That my idea had been that Mr Daschkoff should receive in pure silver (the only fair standard) precisely the same Amount at Washington, that I should receive upon his orders here— That if this arrangement would occasion any loss to Mr Daschkoff, I could neither expect nor desire that he should agree to it— He said that he did not at present exactly know how it would affect him; but he would ascertain, and give me a further answer— I wrote little— Walked before dinner—& in the Evening read Voltaire. -28. -18:7. -21:3.

7. The weather has at length moderated, and the thermometer this day was at about -10 degrees. I rose by daylight— Read prayers for the fifth Sunday after the Epiphany, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the Character of Felix— It is unusually desultory, and has apparently no unity of topic— But its principal argument is an invective against avarice— I read also Mayhew’s Sermon 14 to Young Men— The rest of the day, instead of writing as I ought to have done I was poring upon Chronology— Bedford’s Scripture Chronology, Lenglet, du Fresnoy; and Count John Potocki>— In XV. Genesis 13. The Lord tells Abram that his posterity shall dwell and be persecuted in a strange land, four hundred years— And in XII. Exodus 40. It is said that the children of Israël dwelt in Egypt 430 years— Now I had always considered these 430 years as commencing from the time when Jacob went with his children into Egypt, and settled in the land of Goshen, and was surprised to find all these Chronologists reckoning the 400 years from the weaning of Isaac, and the 430 from the time of the promise made to Abram— How the residence of Abram himself can be included under that of the children of Israël his Grandson, I do not yet perceive. Nor do I know exactly where lies the necessity for fixing upon these dates— Count John Potocki says that without it the Hebrews would have no Chronology; but I know not why— If I had Calmet, or Usher, I might find the difficulty solved; as yet I am to enquire further. I walked only before dinner; and part of the Evening was idle. -19:2. -10:2. -7:2.

8. Visits this morning from Mr Harris and Mr Saltus. Mr Harris mentioned that it had been just discovered that a large amount of forged Assignation Bank-Bills were in circulation— That they came from Moscow and from Riga, and are said to have been brought in by the French— Mr Saltus wished for Courier’s Passports, and expects to go next week with Mr Dimond— I received from the Department of the Ceremonies, a Notice for a Court to-morrow— It being the Grand-Duke Michael’s Birth-day.— A day of which no notice has ever before been taken since we have been here— As there has been no Court hitherto this Winter, and all the days on which they were heretofore usual have been passed by, this notice was quite unexpected to me— Miss Frederica Bode, who dined with us and spent the Evening here, told us she was the cause of it— She is a demoiselle de Cour to the Princess Amelia of Baden, the Empresses Sister— And having heard many Gentlemen of the Corps Diplomatique complaining that they had no opportunity, of making their Court to the Empresses, and the Spanish Secretaries and Attachés, not having even been presented she had mentioned it to the Princess, and the Princess she supposed to the Empress, and that was the occasion of the Cercle— Countess Colombi, and her Sister Clementine, who has just returned from Jarosleff were also here on a Morning visit to the Ladies.— In the Evening I finished reading the second Volume of Voltaire’s Essai sur les Moeurs— The cold continues relaxing, and this morning I found my thermometer at one degree above 0.— The greatest rigour of the Winter I trust is past.

9. At noon I went with Mr Smith to the Winter Palace, where after the Imperial family had attended Mass, the Empresses held a diplomatic circle— It was attended by the British Ambassador Lord Cathcart, His two Sons and Aids, Captain M’Donald and Captain Forbes, and Mr Bailey the British Consul— By the Duke de Serra-Capriola, and his Son (Two Sicilies) Baron Blome—(Denmark) Mr Krabbe, his Secy of Legation was unwell, and not there— Count Löwenhielm (Sweden) with his nephew and Aid, and Mr Brandel his Secretary. Count Maistre, (Sardinia) and the Chevalier Bardaxi Azara (Spain—Ferdinand 7.) with the Chevalier Carnerero his Secretary of Legation attached to the Mission, and Captains Lema, Secy of Legation, and Parada, attached to the Mission— These Gentlemen were presented to the Empresses— Captain Guedes was not there. The Empresses were very short in their conversation. Talked about the weather, and to me about my wife and absent Children. The Empress-Mother said there had been 30 degrees of cold, and that the Mercury had been frozen— After the Circle the whole Corps Diplomatique were conducted into the Grand Duke Michael’s Apartments, and he held a Circle— This was a novelty both to him and to us. He is the youngest of the Emperor Paul’s children, and this day fifteen years old— He has grown to manhood since we arrived here— He was in his twelfth year when I was first presented to him— This day he went through the Ceremony very well for a first time— Spoke to Baron Blome of his fine horses, and asked me if I had any late news from America— He must be nearly full-grown; is nearly six feet tall, and very strongly resembles the Emperor— Before the Cercle, while we were assembled in the introductory Apartment Count Romanzoff came in— He took me aside, and told me that he was very sorry to be the bearer of bad news to me of Mr Barlow.— That Prince Kurakin had written from Vienna, that he was dead. He had been sent for last Summer to Willna— But after waiting some time at Warsaw, he had determined to return through Cracow, and Vienna to Paris.— On the road he was taken sick, and died at Cracow.— Prince Kurakin mentioned this Event in his letter with great concern. During the latter part of the time preceding the War, the Prince had seen nobody at Paris, but him; and there was no sort of kindness and attention that Mr Barlow had not shewn him. The Prince had even deposited with him the Archives of the Russian Embassy at Paris, and was now anxious about them— The Count said he had no doubt but that on leaving Paris, Mr Barlow had taken care to leave them in some safe custody; but he wished me to write concerning it— I told him I would write immediately, if he would have the goodness to indicate a mode to me of transmitting the letter— The Count asked me if I could not send it through Baron Blome, by the way of Denmark. He added that he had particular reasons for not wishing to point out to me a direct mode of Communication— I replied that I would very readily ask Baron Blome, to transmit a letter for me; or if I could send directly to Vienna; I would take that course— I had also some conversation with the Chevalier Bardaxi, for the first time— He had seemed before this to avoid it, and Countess Colombi had told Mrs Adams that he had some scruples whether to consider Spain and the United States at Peace— He was however now very communicative; and told me that when our Declaration of War against England had appeared he was at Lisbon; where the Portuguese Government had declared themselves neutral, and issued an Ordinance prohibiting the admission of prizes into their ports, by either party—that he had recommended the same course, and the same regulation to his own Government, and they had accordingly adopted them both. The exclusion of prizes, he
said, was suggested to him as necessary, by the embarrassments and controversies into which they had been drawn, particularly with America, by having been obliged to admit prizes made by the French, into their Ports, during the last War— I told him I thought the regulation a very good one, and wished it could be made an universal law of neutrality.— Lord Cathcart spoke to me about the weather— We came home between 2 and 3. I walked before dinner; and passed the Evening in hearing Charles read, and playing with him at the Grammatical lessons.— Rose this morning at 5. Read and wrote 3 hours by Candle-light.

10. Mr: Smith wrote a Note to Mr Delprat requesting him to call upon me this morning which he did— He had some weeks ago applied to me to ask if I could obtain a Courier’s Passport for him to go to Vienna, and to Paris— I had then declined, having no particular motive for writing to France— But having now, that, occasioned by Mr Barlow’s decease, I informed Mr Delprat that I would ask a Passport for him, if he would go as a Courier to Paris, and would at all Events write by him, if he went with the ordinary Passports— He said he should be ready to go next Sunday.— that he had now his Passports to leave this Country; and would take my letters; or if he could go through Vienna, would proceed as a Courier to Paris immediately, should I procure for him the Courier’s Passport— I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff, requesting to see him for the purpose of knowing whether he has any objection to my sending a Courier to Paris; thinking it best to ascertain this before I make the application in writing. He answered me appointing to morrow Evening at 6 O’Clock— Mr: Harris spent the Evening with us, and told me that Mr Swienin had written to him stating that he had made an Application to Count Romanzoff, for a privilege to introduce the Steam-Boats here on a plan much superior to Mr Fulton’s; and requesting him to sollicit Count Romanzoff, in his behalf.— I rose again at 5 and read and wrote untill Breakfast time. Charles read one of Bouilly’s tales in the Evening.

11. Mr Lewis called upon me this morning, apparently in some agitation; he had formed here a commercial partnership with two brothers, Christian and Peter Von Essen; but being dissatisfied with them, the partnership was dissolved at the close of the last year— The House was in the name of Peter Von Essen, who was written up, as they term it, or registered, and had paid the tax as a Merchant of the first Guild, according to the Law and Custom of the Country— Neither Lewis nor Willing, the other American partner had been written up— The Cargoes of several American vessels were consigned to them; part of which is sold upon credit; and part remains in possession of the house—that is to say of Peter Von Essen, the recorded merchant— In coming to a settlement of their Affairs the partners have quarreled— By an Article of their partnership, they bound themselves in a penalty of 50000 Rubles, in case any difference between them should arise, to abide by the arbitration of Benedict Cramer, and Joshua Martin— Yesterday they left a Question to Benedict Cramer, who decided it in Lewis’s favour— Von Essen, refused to abide by it, and this day went to the Compting-House; took away two of the Books, and forbad the Clerk, who was their Cashier, from receiving any money for the goods sold, untill further orders from him— Mr Lewis thought I could obtain from Count Romanzoff, an order to take the books and all the property out of the hands of Peter Von Essen, and to deliver them to him— I told him that though disposed to render him every service in my power, I could not apply to Count Romanzoff for such an order, knowing that he would answer me, that it was a subject out of his Department, which must be left to the tribunals of the Country— He was very reluctant at resorting to the Law, which is in no higher repute here than elsewhere. I advised him then to compromise the matter as amicably and as advantageously as he could; but he seemed to think that impossible— He spoke to me about Mr Fisher, of whom he mentioned circumstances which I was sorry to hear.— I received from Count Romanzoff a second Note, desiring me to come at half past seven this Evening, instead of six; and at his house on the Quay— I accordingly went, and mentioned to him that in consequence of the information of Mr: Barlow’s death, I had thought of sending a Messenger by the way of Vienna to Paris; as well to ascertain the situation of our own affairs in France, as to give the necessary directions with regard to the security of the Archives of the Russian Embassy which had been deposited with him. That one of my Countrymen here who was desirous of going through Vienna to Paris had asked me some time ago, if I could not send dispatches by him, and obtain a Courier’s Passport for him; which I had then declined, having no special motive for sending dispatches, and wishing to avoid every unnecessary correspondence with France in the state of affairs between that Nation and Russia— But that now having a sufficient motive of public interest for it, I should request a Courier’s Passport for him, if there was no objection to granting one. The Count said that he would with pleasure give a Passport, to go either to Vienna, or to Copenhagen; or anywhere, but directly to Paris; that he might not have the appearance of knowing that the Courier was destined there— That he thought I was right in sending a special Messenger on this occasion, and I had an undoubted right to dispatch a Courier to the Agent of the United States in France, with whom they were at Peace— That he was sensible to the delicacy, I had shewn in previously consulting him to enquire, if he should have any objection to this measure— That he
had none whatsoever— But his Passport would avail, only as far as the frontier— That the Austrians might stop the Courier, and not permit him to proceed to Vienna— They had already done so by some Prussian Officers, to whom he had given Passports; who had been full of zeal, and considered this as their own Cause— But the pusillanimous Austrians, from the fear of giving Offence to the French Government had refused them permission to go to Vienna— He asked if I could not obtain a Courier’s Passport from the Duke de Serra-Capriola— I said that I should prefer giving him my own— That the United States had indeed no Minister at Vienna; but that they were at Peace with Austria, and I could see no reason why they should refuse admission or passage to an American Courier. I said I would also give him a letter to the French Ambassador at Vienna, who was an acquaintance of mine of nearly 35 years standing, and whom I should request to facilitate the admission of my Courier into France— The Count said he saw no reason why the Austrians should not respect my Passport, and that it would therefore be unnecessary to ask for any other— We had then some further desultory Conversation. He said he had English Gazettes to 8 January— That the renewal of the East-India Company’s Charter was the subject which appeared most to occupy the public attention there at present, and to occasion some temporary and local agitation— That in Spain they appeared to be doing nothing at-all, and Lord Wellington had retreated into Portugal— I said the French could do nothing at all there neither; but I had heard they had not withdrawn any troops from there— The Count said he did not know.— I observed that if they had not withdrawn them, they very shortly must resort to that expedient— How else could they supply the place of that immense army they had lost in the North?— This brought the Count to talk of the destruction of Napoleon’s Army, which he said was so complete that scarcely any but the Officers had escaped— It reminded him of an Anecdote of the Comte de Clermont, who commanded the French Army in Germany, in the seven years War. He had suffered a great defeat, and dispersion of his troops; and was passing through a City, and stopp’d at a public house, where upon his enquiring of the Landlady Avéz vous un quelqu’un de nos fuyards?—she answered him “Non— Monseigneur est le premier.” An Answer which would now be perfectly applicable to a great number of Napoleon’s Marshals and Generals.— My interview with the Count was short and I came home before nine.— It was certain that Providence had reserved to itself almost entirely the agency in this Event— It was beyond all human calculation that the fame and glory of the Emperor Napoleon, founded on an uninterrupted succession of Victories for nearly twenty years, and which had become a sort of Religion in Europe, should thus have vanished in the course of three months, before an old man of seventy-two years of age, whose own military reputation was a problem; and of whom many people here extolled very highly, while as many others held him in contempt— The Count alluded by this to Prince Kutuzoff-Smolensky, who certainly has very little contributed to the disasters of Napoleon and his Army.— I came home before nine.

12. I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff, requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr Delprat to go to Vienna— Mr Smith by my desire called upon Baron Marechal, who before the War, was one of the Secretaries of the Austrian Legation, and who since it commenced has remained here—to ask if he could give any Passport, or endorse mine; so that Mr Delprat might be admitted over the Austrian frontier, and allowed to proceed to Vienna— He said the only thing he could give was a letter to the Governor of Radziwiloff the frontier town; upon which he could obtain a Passport from Vienna to proceed— This he promised.— Mr Dimond called upon me concerning his Passport as a Courier, and said he was now ready to go, whenever it would suit my convenience— I told him that having by the unexpected information of Mr Barlow’s death, occasion to ask for another Courier’s Passport for Mr Delprat, I should not be ready for him so soon as I had expected, and must ask him to wait two or three days longer, to which he very readily agreed. He had not yet settled with Mr Saltus, whether they should go together, or not; but he will inform me on Monday— Mrs Krehmer paid a morning visit to Mrs Adams— She had seen English Newspapers to 9 January, and said there was in them a confirmation of the capture of the British frigate Arethusa, which had sometime before been reported and contradicted.— In my walk before dinner I met Mr Slade, who had heard nothing of this news.— Lord Cathcart, the British Ambassador, left the City last Night, to go to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters— Mr Plummer spent the Evening with us— It was my wife’s birth-day— She and Catherine are again both quite unwell.

13. Mrs Adams was again confined the whole day to her bed— Mr Delprat came to enquire if his Passports were ready— I received the one from Count Romanzoff in the Evening. Dined at the Count’s with a company of about 30 persons— The foreign Ministers and military Officers. My neighbours at table were an old General whom I did not know; and Admiral Gregg, who arrived three days ago from England by the
way of Torneo, and who told me he was going away again to-morrow Morning to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters— I had much Conversation with him at table, upon indifferent topics.— Lord Cathcart went yesterday to join the Emperor— His youngest Son, and Captain Gordon, were at this dinner— Count Romanzoff told me he had this morning seen an Article in a very late Vienna Gazette, concerning the Death of Mr Barlow—that it was at a Post-station before he reached Cracow—that his nephew was with him, and had gone on to Paris to give notice of the Event— The Count added he believed that his death was owing to the want of medical assistance, which at that place could not be obtained.— I came home between 6 and 7 and employed the Evening in reading Dutens or Duchillon’s Memoires d’un Voyageur qui se repose— He was though born a Frenchman, long employed in the English legations abroad—as Chaplain— Secretary of Embassy and Chargé d’Affaires— His Book is a series of Anecdotes concerning many of the most distinguished diplomatic and political characters in Europe; during the last half of the 18th: Century— They are interesting, and told in a lively manner.

14. I gave Mr Delprat his Passports, with two Copies of a letter to the Chargé d’Affaires of the United States at Paris— One in Cypher to be forwarded by Mr Delprat, if he should be detained short of Paris, and the other uncyphered to be delivered only by himself in person. A letter from Baron Marechal, to the Count de Goës Governor of Welomeria and Gallicia, at Lemberg, the Austrian frontier, to obtain permission for him to proceed to Vienna; and a letter from me to Count Otto the French Ambassador at Vienna, requesting him to facilitate the passage of Mr Delprat to Paris— Count Romanzoff sent me a large packet, and Mr Schoulépoff another, for the Chevalier d’Ott a Russian Counsellor of State now at Vienna; both of which I delivered to Mr Delprat, requesting him to deliver them himself, and to take a receipt for them— He went away this afternoon. I received Notice of a Court to be held at Noon to-morrow.— Mrs Adams is still confined to her bed— I read Prayers, for Septuagesima Sunday; and Sterne’s Sermon upon the Story of the Prodigal Son— There is something exquisitely tender and pathetic in this parable, without any mixture of the horrible incidents which form the history of the Levite and his Concubine. But Christ, who on this as on many other occasions, so irresistibly addressed the feelings and imagination of his hearers, never mingled the burlesque with the pathetic— It is expressly recorded upon one occasion that Jesus wept; but it is never mentioned that he laughed, and in all his discourses there is not a word that had a tendency to excite laughter in his disciples.— Solomon says there is a time to laugh and as it is one of the pleasures of life which may at times be indulged with innocence it would be rather cynical rigour than virtue to proscribe it— But the pulpit is not the place for laughter— Religion is a subject upon which the mind should be too earnestly intent, for joking— In a Comedy, or a Poem upon the story of the prodigal Son, the Apes and Peacocks that lay dead upon his hands, and the Mummies that had not been dead long enough, the man of honour by whom he had been sold to a maker of graven images, and the whore of Babylon who swallowed his pearl, would furnish excellent materials for dramatic scenes, or poetical descriptions; but they are not suitable for a Sermon— The Satirical remarks upon the custom of sending young Englishmen of rank and fortune, to travel; or make what was called the tour of Europe, do not appear to arise very naturally from the story of the prodigal— But the picture of his departure and of his return, and especially the description of the father’s feelings are inexpressibly affecting.— I read also Mayhew’s 15th: and last Sermon to young Men— They are so excellent, that I am surprized they are not more in circulation in the Country where they were delivered. There were features in the character of this writer, bearing some resemblance to that of Sterne— He is sometimes keenly satirical, and sometimes uses irony, with an archness, that excites a smile— But he has little Imagination, and less power of pathos. He is always profoundly earnest, both in doctrine and reproof, and his morality though sufficiently indulgent, is not relaxed and equivocal like Sterne’s. In the Evening I read part of the Dutensiana—the 3d: Volume, added to the two of the Voyageur qui se repose— It is much less amusing; and seems to be the last scrapings of his Port-Folio.

15. At Noon I went with Mr Smith to the Winter Palace, and attended the Court held by the Empresses, it being the Russian festival of St: Ann, and accordingly the name day of the Grand-Duchesses Anna Paulovna, the Emperor’s Sister, and Anna Feodorovna, the Grand-Duke Constantine’s wife— (She has been many years absent in Germany.) They also include in this day the keeping of the Grand Duchess Mary’s birth-day— She is Duchess of Saxe-Weimar— It was heretofore customary to solemnize this day in the same manner; and in 1810 the Court was notified, but countermanded on the morning of the day. The two succeeding years it was kept at Gatschina.— This day, the Empress Mother asked me about the wedding that is to be in my house—when it was to be— I told her this week— She asked me, if in America, marriages were solemnized in lent; and she was much astonished on my telling her that in America, we kept no lent— The Empress asked me about the death of Mr Barlow— After this general Circle, we went to the Grand Duchess Ann’s Apartments, where she held a special one— She spoke to me about Mrs: Adams’s health, and the severity of the Climate.— I asked the Chevalier Bardaxi whether he had seen the paragraphs in the English Newspapers, about Mr: Barlow’s pretended journey to Moscow, to make a Treaty against Spain— He said he had not— Count Löwenhielm promised to lend me the
English Newspapers, and give me a Copy of a diplomatic paper, of which several copies had been sent to him to distribute. After returning from Court I sent for the News papers; which were the Courier to 8. January, and which I spent almost the whole Evening in reading— Mrs Adams was up about half an hour before dinner; but was obliged to go to bed again quite ill.

16. I rose this morning at day-light, as now happens about once a week. It materially affects my occupations for the day— Mr Fisher called upon me this morning with Mr Baer who arrived here a few days since from Moscow— He was there at the time when the City was taken by the French, and lost much property by the pillage and burning of the place— Mr Diamond came to enquire about his Passports, and to tell me that Mr Saltus would go with him— I wrote Notes to Count Romanzoff, and Count Löwenhielm, requesting the Passports— After the severe cold which lasted so long, we have now a great thaw, which has already ruined the roads and streets for sledging— It also affects my health— The extraordinary nervous tension occasioned by the cold is followed by a relaxation that is painful and troublesome— I make the Evenings as short as I can. Mrs Adams is still quite unwell; and was up only a small part of this day— Mr Diamond and Mr Fisher mentioned to me a Manifesto of the English Regent’s against the United States, in Answer to that of the American Government on the Declaration of War.

17. Rose by Candle-light and read and wrote three hours before Breakfast. I received from Count Romanzoff, the Passport for Mr Diamond, with a packet for Mr Daschkoff to be sent by him— This Evening William Steuben Smith, and Catherine Maria Frances Johnson were married at my house by Dr Beresford, Rector of the English Church at Moscow— The record of the Marriage was entered on the Register of the English Church in this City; and the witnesses who subscribed their names to the record were, Levett Harris the American Consul, William Lewis, and J. T. Slade, Citizens of the United States residing here, my wife and myself— The marriage was solemnized conformably to the Laws of this Country, and in the forms of the English Episcopal Church— Mr Harris brought with him and lent me the British Regent’s Declaration, in Answer to our Manifesto at the commencement of the War.

18. Rose before 5 and read and wrote untill Breakfast-time— Mr Diamond was here after breakfast. I gave him the Passport from Count Romanzoff, and the packet for Mr Daschkoff—the Pass from Count Löwenhielm I had not received— Mr Harris passed two hours with us this Evening— I received letters from Mr Forbes at Copenhagen, and Mr Speyer at Stockholm announcing Mr Barlow’s death. Answered the first of them, which employed all the leisure of the Evening.

19. Rose after daylight and proportionably shortened the day— Prepared my packets to send by Mr Diamond but he did not come for them. Mr Lewis called upon me this morning. He had some late news from England, and America, but none of material importance— I sent for a French pamphlet just published here upon the influence of a great power, united with great Moderation, for the good of humanity.— It appears to be a renewal of the Abbe de St: Pierre’s project for a general league of Peace, and its object is to suggest the idea to the Emperor Alexander, of undertaking such a plan, and carrying it into execution— The author must be a German, Italian, or Spaniard by the phraseology; which is neither French, nor even so good French as the Russians who learn that language are accustomed to write— A political pamphlet on topics of general interest to the whole civilized world is a phenomenon in this Country— I employed part of the Evening with Charles at his grammatical lesson, and the remainder in reading Dutens’s Memoirs.

20. Mr Diamond came this morning and I gave him the Passport from Count Löwenhielm, and my own packets and letters that I had ready for him— We had company to dinner, Messrs: Baer, Beresford, Fisher, Gair, Gibson, Hall, Harris, Lewis, Plummer, Proud, Redwood, Slade, J. W. Smith, Tilden, and Willing.— I had invited Messrs: Calhoun and Montreal, who sent excuses, and Mr Diamond, who excused himself this morning. He intended to leave the City this Evening, or to-morrow Morning. The gentlemen most of them also passed the Evening here.— Mr Lewis shewed me a letter from Mr Connell who is at Stockholm, containing some English and American News— I employed part of the day in preparing an Index for my private letter-Book.

21. Read prayers for Sexagesima Sunday, and Sterne’s Sermon, under the title of National Mercies considered; which was preached upon some political occasion, and is of a political character. It differs therefore from the generality of those with which it is collected having very little either of ludicrous or pathetic— It is an ordinary Thanksgiving discourse— Mr Krehmer was here on a Morning visit, and mentioned the death of the English Admiral Bentinck; of a pleurisy fever, caught by exposing himself in the severity of this Season, without the sort of garments indispensible to guard against it— In the Evening I read something of Dutens, and looked over pictures with Charles—received notice for a Te Deum to-morrow morning, at the Cazan Church.

22. At eleven this morning, I went with Mr Smith to the Cazan Church, and attended the Te Deum for the taking of Warsaw, and of the fortress of Pillou— The keys of Warsaw, a couple of old brass keys were exhibited. The Empresses and Imperial family now in the City were present. But the
crowd was much smaller than at the former Te Deum’s in this Church— Baron Blome told me that he had received a Courier from Copenhagen yesterday— That his Government had made a proposal to England for a Negotiation of Peace— That it was quite uncertain whether the French Government itself would not negotiate— That in Paris there was great uncertainty, and vacillation— That there was a great party there for Peace, and for forcing the Government to negotiate— So that it was necessary for every one to think of himself.— After we came home I received letters from Mr Beasley, and Mr Fosdick, enclosing one of 29. July last from my Mother—the latest I have yet from America— Mr Proud called upon me, and delivered me a letter from Amsterdam, which he had received under cover from Copenhagen. He also read me parts of some letters which he had himself received— In the Evening I heard Charles read a Tale of Bouilly’s, and finished reading the first Volume of Dutens’s Memoirs— I rose an hour before daylight, and walked only before dinner.

23. This morning I finished making the Index to my private letter Book, containing my private letters from October 1801. on my return from my first public missions to Europe, untill March 1812— During the eight years that I was in America, my correspondence was inconsiderable, and I kept copies, only of a small portion of the letters that I wrote. 65 pages comprize the correspondence of almost seven years. There are a number of letters, of which I now wish I had kept copies; but as they were chiefly to my father, mother and brother I may hereafter have access to them again. I have now formed another project of occupation, which may engage me for some weeks if I have patience, and perseverance to accomplish my own purpose— I began upon it this morning, but wrote very little— In the Evening I heard Charles read in Bouilly, and read myself in the second Volume of Dutens— Mr and Mrs Smith passed the Evening at Madame Colombi’s.

24. I still rise before daylight, and was employed this morning, untill breakfast in writing— Captain Bates called upon me this forenoon, and Mr Harris paid us an Evening visit— The thaw continues, and makes the streets almost impassible— Mrs Adams was again unwell, and kept her bed great part of the day— I read something in Dutens’s Memoirs Vol. 2.

25. Rose about five, and after reading an hour resumed my walk before breakfast, which during the excessive cold weather, I had omitted, and in the unusual thaw which succeeded I had not yet recommenced— I had a morning visit from the Chevalier Bardaxi Azara, the Spanish Minister, accompanied by Don Francisco Zea Bermudez, who Styles himself Plenipotentiary of Ferdinand 7— Mr Bardaxi was in high Spirits, and extremely sangwine, at the present situation of political affairs. He says there was a Courier from the Army yesterday— That Russian troops had passed the Oder, and that Count Woronzoff would shortly be at Berlin. That there was to be a personal interview between the Emperor Alexander, and the king of Prussia, near Breslaw— That the Russian army was every where received with such enthusiasm of joy that there would immediately be 150,000 men raised in Prussia, to fight against the French— That Austria likewise manifested a disposition to negotiate separately— I mentioned that an Austrian Courier had been said to have passed through Holland, and arrived at London, early in January, with very important dispatches— He said that was nothing but the mediation—in which he supposed Austria was not sincere— Austria had made an offer of her mediation, for a general Peace, which Napoleon had accepted,—and his acceptance had been formally communicated to the several European Courts— But it was in terms which evidently shewed that he had no intention to make peace— It said that he accepted the mediation of his puissant allié the Emperor of Austria; and would declare the basis on which he would negotiate, referring to his offer made to England last April, and adding to it, that Prussia must remain as heretofore; and Russia not to acquire a line, beyond her present Territory— Turkey to remain as by the Peace of last Summer, at Bucharest.— I asked him if he had any late news from England—he said none—there could be no important news from thence— It was in the North that the destiny of Europe must be settled— Mr Ducornau likewise called upon me, and I promised to obtain Courier’s Passports for him— In the Evening I read Dutens— Mrs Adams was extremely ill all the morning, and confined to her bed the whole day— Charles finished reading the Acts, in his progress through the New Testament— He is also learning the multiplication Table.

26. Morning visit from Mr Montreal— Walk before Breakfast and again before dinner— The weather has again become clear and cold, and this Evening the thermometer was at -16— Mrs Adams was again quite unwell the whole day, and very ill in the Evening— Mr: and Mrs Smith, dined with Miss Frederica Bode, at her Apartments in the Palace— Charles Began reading the Epistle to the Romans— In the Evening he read one of Bouilly’s tales.— I read a few pages of Dutens; but although I rise now with tolerable constancy as early as 6 in the Morning, I find myself so shortened for leisure that I scarcely read any thing— I am not much more successful in writing.

27. Walk before Breakfast. The thermometer at -16. Rode with Charles in the sleigh. On my return I paid a visit to the Chevalier Bardaxi Azara, with whom I found Mr Zea— The Chevalier had some late Newspapers from England; with the Regent’s declaration against America— He said he thought it a very feeble piece; but he thought the question between the United States and England, upon which the War now turned was an extremely difficult one to settle.— He spoke of the English manner of negotiating, and of their ideas of reciprocity, which he said was always a reciprocity of words, with the substance all on their own side— He instanced particularly in their late Treaty with Portugal, made at Rio de Janeiro— I asked him if there were any News from America in his Papers, but he did not appear to know— In the Evening I finished Dutens, Vol. 2. Charles read one of Bouilly’s tales.

28. Rose by day-light, though soon after 6 this Morning— The Sun now rises at seven. Between Noon and One O’Clock I went with Mr Smith, to the Winter-Palace, and attended the Te Deum for a Victory of General Winzingerode over the Corps, commanded by General Regnier— I met there besides the usual Members of the Corps Diplomatique, Sir Francis D’Ivernois, whom at his request Mr Harris introduced to me— He told me that he had formerly been acquainted with my father in London; and had since been in Correspondence with him— That my father in one of his Publications had given him a title which did not belong to him; that of Doctor— He believed that the mistake had arisen, from his having once dined with my father at Dr: Price’s; and from Doctor Price’s having then several times at table addressed him, he did not know why as Doctor D’Ivernois— Sir Francis, who since that time has been knighted by the King of England, doubtless considers the title of Doctor, as a sort of degradation, and it must have lain heavy upon his mind, for him to have made it after an interval of more than twenty-five years the first topic of Conversation with me. He had before mentioned it to Mr Harris— He also told me that he was now going to travel over a Country, through which he knew that I had also been, and concerning which I had published a Book— He had not seen it— We had some further Conversation, which was however very soon interrupted, by the summons to the Te Deum. It was shorter than usual— On returning home, I read prayers for Quinquagesima Sunday, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the character of Jacob— In the Evening I read part of Cicero’s first Dialogue upon the Nature of the Gods; in Olivet’s Translation; comparing it frequently with the Original—

Day. Untill this morning, I have with very few exceptions risen by candle-light through the course of this Month, and usually employed the morning untill 10 O’Clock in reading and writing. Sometimes but not often I have walked before Breakfast an hour or more— Immediately after Breakfast, I hear Charles read two Chapters in the English New Testament, and have now added a short lesson of the multiplication Table— From thence untill half past three P.M— I pass the time in my Chamber reading and writing, and seeing such visitors as call to see me— Walk an hour and a half untill dinner, which is at five; and usually continues untill seven— Two hours of the Evening I read, or hear Charles read French; and share in his amusements to pass the time— At 9 the family take tea; and from ten to eleven I retire to bed— I never go abroad in the Evening, and we scarcely ever have any visitors at home. My wife has been confined to her chamber almost the whole Month—to her bed, great part of it. My anxiety for the state of her health is deep, and constant— Other anxieties both of a public and private Nature embitter the hours, and allow not that tranquility which I implore— Anticipation is gloomy and threatening— Nothing but the blessing of divine Providence can give to the realities which Time must bring forth a more propitious character— I importune Heaven with unceasing prayer— Let me Hope, that I shall at least be heard, in asking for Fortitude equal to my Trials, and for light to guide my steps through the path before me!
